title: 113_s1704
content:
The Act may be cited as the "Affordable College Textbook Act." The high cost of college textbooks is a barrier for many students. Average student budget for books and supplies is $1,200. Textbook prices have increased 82% in the last decade. The Internet has enabled the creation and sharing of open educational resources. Using open educational resources in large college courses can reduce textbook costs by 80 to 100 percent. Federal investment in expanding open educational resources could significantly lower college textbook costs and reduce financial barriers to higher education. SEC. 3. DEFINITIONS. In this Act, definitions include terms like "educational resource" for materials used in postsecondary instruction, "institution of higher education" as defined in the Higher Education Act of 1965, "open educational resource" as freely available online with an open license, and "open license" granting public permission for various uses. The term "open textbook" refers to freely available educational resources that can be used in place of a textbook for postsecondary courses, with the condition that attribution is given to authors. The term "Secretary" in this context refers to the Secretary of Education. The grant program is established. The Secretary will provide grants to eligible entities for pilot programs expanding the use of open textbooks in higher education. Eligible entities are institutions of higher education. Applications must be submitted with project descriptions. The grant application must include a project description, a plan for promoting open textbooks in postsecondary courses, evaluating existing resources, quality review, and dissemination of project results to higher education institutions. The grant application must include a project description, plan for promoting open textbooks in postsecondary courses, evaluating existing resources, quality review, and dissemination of project results to higher education institutions. Special consideration is given to applications with the greatest potential to achieve savings for students through expanded use of open textbooks in postsecondary courses and to expand the use of open textbooks at institutions of higher education. An eligible entity receiving a grant must produce high-quality open textbooks that are easily utilized and adapted by faculty members, correspond to high enrollment courses, and are created or adapted in partnership with entities for marketing and distribution. Grant funds are to be used for professional development for faculty and staff members to expand the use of open textbooks. The grant funds support professional development, creation, and adaptation of open educational resources, tools development, research on open textbook efficacy, and partnerships with other entities. Educational resources must be licensed under an open license for access and distribution. The grant funds support the creation and adaptation of open educational resources, which must be made available for free on an easily accessible website in a machine-readable format. Upon completion of a project, an eligible entity must submit a report to the Secretary on the effectiveness of the pilot program in expanding the use of open textbooks and achieving savings for students. Authorization of Appropriations: Sums are authorized for the next 5 fiscal years to support the creation and adaptation of open educational resources, including project costs and volunteer labor. SEC. 5. PRICE INFORMATION.

Amends Section 133(b) of the Higher Education Act of 1965 to update the definition of a college textbook to include various formats like printed materials, computer disks, website access, and electronically distributed materials.

SEC. 6. SENSE OF CONGRESS.

Congress encourages higher education institutions to consider open textbooks within the principles of academic freedom for faculty to choose the most suitable course materials.

SEC. 7. REPORT TO CONGRESS. SEC. 7. REPORT TO CONGRESS.

The Secretary must submit a report to Congress by July 1, 2016, detailing the creation or adaptation of open textbooks, their adoption, and the savings generated for students, States, and the Federal Government through their use. The Comptroller General of the United States is required to submit a report by July 1, 2017, to the Senate and House committees on the cost of textbooks in higher education. The report will analyze the changes in textbook costs, factors contributing to these changes, the use of open textbooks in higher education, and the impact of open textbooks on textbook costs.
